entry.title: DRACO and AWN Partner in year-long collaborative research.

link.title: DRACO and AWN Partner in year-long collaborative research.

entry.content:
The DRACO lab secures 165K in funding from Arctic Wolf Networks to investigate properties of AI workloads.

The project leverages prior work in analyzing complex algorithms through run-time observations, the industry research grant was awarded UCF DRACO PI Mike Borowczak
and the research leads for the project are Master’s students Alicia Thoney and Calvin VanWormer.
entry.summary: The DRACO lab secures 165K in funding from Arctic Wolf Networks to investigate properties of AI workloads.

entry.title: UCF Awarded 2 Year NSF Noyce WRNN Subaward

link.title: UCF Awarded 2 Year NSF Noyce WRNN Subaward

entry.content:
DRACO secures a 2-year NSF Noyce Western Regional Noyce Network (WRNN) Subaward for 100K.

The DRACO lab’s PI Mike Borowczak and the School of Teacher Education’s Director Andrea Borowczak received a two year subaward from NSF NOYCE WRNN to enable building of community amongst STEM educators bringing CS into their classrooms. Free Professional developments at the intersection of AI-CS-STEM Instruction are planned for 2025/2026.
entry.summary: DRACO secures a 2-year NSF Noyce Western Regional Noyce Network (WRNN) Subaward for 100K.

entry.title: Presentation & Leadership at ASEE 2024!
entry.content:
Congratulations to Drs. Borowczak & Borowczak on their recent ASEE 2024 work and Mike’s new role as ASEE Computers in Education division Program Chair!

The DRACO lab’s PI Mike Borowczak and the School of Teacher Education’s Director Andrea Borowczak presented results from two multi-year NSF awards at the 2024 American Society for Engineering Education annual Conference in Portland, Oregon.

The paper behind their presented work, “Integrating Computing Throughout K-12 While Bridging the Digital Divide” is now freely available through ASEE Peer.

Additionally, Mike, who serves as the Editor for the ASEE Computers in Education Journal, now also assumes the role of Program Chair of the Computers in Education Division for the next two annual conferences (2025, 2026).
entry.summary: Congratulations to Drs. Borowczak & Borowczak on their recent ASEE 2024 work and Mike’s new role as ASEE Computers in Education division Program Chair!

entry.title: SAGA paper accepted at MWSCAS 2024!
entry.content:
Congratulations to Andey on having their paper accepted to MWSCAS 2024!

The DRACO lab’s Andey Robins and Mike Borowczak recently had their paper “SAGA: Synthesis Augmentation with Genetic Algorithms for In-Memory Sequence Optimization” accepted to the 2024 IEEE 67th International Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems (MWSCAS) which is the North American flagship conference of the IEEE Circuits and Systems (CAS) Society. You can view the pre-print of the paper on ArXiV. The SAGA Code is open source and licensed under the GPLv3 license.
entry.summary: Congratulations to Andey on having their paper accepted to MWSCAS 2024!

entry.title: Students Present Three Posters at IEEE SEED 2024

link.title: Students Present Three Posters at IEEE SEED 2024

entry.content: The International Symposium on Secure and Private Execution Environment Design (SEED) occurred May 16th and 17th at the UCF Fairwinds Alumni Center. Three researchers from the DRACO Lab had the opportunity to present their research in the undergraduate/graduate poster session on Thursday. It was a great experience to learn from professionals and fellow researchers to improve ongoing projects. The wide array of papers presented over the two days was eye-opening with topics from the security of quantum computing to termination and timing channels and more. Overall, it was an incredible opportunity to connect and learn that will help our student researchers develop current and future work.
entry.summary: The International Symposium on Secure and Private Execution Environment Design (SEED) occurred May 16th and 17th at the UCF Fairwinds Alumni Center. Three researchers from the DRACO Lab had the opportunity to present their research in the undergraduate/graduate poster session on Thursday. It was a great experience to learn from professionals and fellow researchers to improve ongoing projects. The wide array of papers presented over the two days was eye-opening with topics from the security of quantum computing to termination and timing channels and more. Overall, it was an incredible opportunity to connect and learn that will help our student researchers develop current and future work.
